introduction.p:
Let us return to limits (Chapter) and see how we can use derivatives to simplify certain families of limits called indeterminate forms. We know, from Theorem on the arithmetic of limits, that if
\lim_{x\rightarrow a}f(x) &= F & \lim_{x\rightarrow a}g(x) &= G
and G\ne 0, then \lim_{x\rightarrow a}\frac{f(x)}{g(x)} &= \frac{F}{G}
The requirement that G\ne 0 is critical we explored this in Example. Please reread that example.

Of course Now it is not so surprising, but perhaps back when we started limits, this was not so obvious. it is not surprising that if F\ne 0 and G= 0, then
\lim_{x\to a}\frac{f(x)}{g(x)} &= DNE
and if F=0 but G\neq 0 then
\lim_{x\to a}\frac{f(x)}{g(x)} &= 0
However when both F,G=0 then, as we saw in Example, almost anything can happen
f(x)&=x & g(x)&=x^2 & \lim_{x\to0} \frac{x}{x^2} &= \lim_{x\to0} \frac{1}{x} = DNE
f(x)&=x^2 & g(x)&=x & \lim_{x\to0} \frac{x^2}{x} &= \lim_{x\to0} x = 0
f(x)&=x & g(x)&=x & \lim_{x\to0} \frac{x}{x} &= \lim_{x\to0} 1 = 1
f(x)&=7x^2 & g(x)&=3x^2 & \lim_{x\to0} \frac{7x^2}{3x^2} &= \lim_{x\to0} \frac{7}{3} = \frac{7}{3}
Indeed after exploring Example and we gave ourselves the rule of thumb that if we found 0/0, then there must be something that cancels.
Because the limit that results from these 0/0 situations is not immediately obvious, but also leads to some interesting mathematics, we should give it a name.

statement.p:
Let a \in \mathbb{R} and let f(x) and g(x) be functions. If
\lim_{x\to a} f(x) &= 0 & \text{and } && \lim_{x\to a} g(x) &= 0
then the limit
\lim_{x\to a} \dfrac{f(x)}{g(x)}
is called a \frac{0}{0} indeterminate form.

introduction.p:
There are quite a number of mathematical tools for evaluating such indeterminate forms Taylor series for example. A simpler method, which works in quite a few cases, is L'Hôpital's rule
Named for the 17th century mathematician, Guillaume de l'Hôpital, who published the first textbook on differential calculus. The eponymous rule appears in that text, but is believed to have been developed by Johann Bernoulli. The book was the source of some controversy since it contained many results by Bernoulli, which l'Hôpital acknowledged in the preface, but Bernoulli felt that l'Hôpital got undue credit. \mbox{ } Note that around that time l'Hôpital's name was commonly spelled l'Hospital, but the spelling of silents in French was changed subsequently; many texts spell his name l'Hospital. If you find yourself in Paris, you can hunt along Boulevard de l'Hôpital for older street signs carved into the sides of buildings which spell it l'Hospital though arguably there are better things to do there. .

statement.p:
Let a\in\mathbb{R} and assume that
\lim_{x\to a}f(x) &= \lim_{x\to a} g(x) = 0
Then
if f'(a) and g'(a) exist and g'(a)\ne 0, then
\lim_{x\to a} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} &=\frac{f'(a)}{g'(a)},
while, if f'(x) and g'(x) exist, with g'(x) nonzero, on an open interval that contains a, except possibly at a itself, and if the limit
\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow a}\frac{f'(x)}{g'(x)} \text{ exists or is $+\infty$ or is $-\infty$}
then
\lim_{x\to a} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} =\lim_{x \to a} \frac{f'(x)}{g'(x)}

proof.p: We only give the proof for part (a). The proof of part (b) is not very difficult, but uses the Generalised MeanValue Theorem (Theorem ), which is optional and most readers have not seen it.

ul.li:
First note that we must have f(a)=g(a)=0. To see this note that since derivative f'(a) exists, we know that the limit
\lim_{x\to a} \frac{f(x)-f(a)}{x-a} & \text{ exists}
Since we know that the denominator goes to zero, we must also have that the numerator goes to zero (otherwise the limit would be undefined). Hence we must have
\lim_{x\to a} (f(x)-f(a)) &= \left( \lim_{x\to a} f(x) \right) - f(a) = 0
We are told that \ds \lim_{x\to a} f(x) =0 so we must have f(a)=0. Similarly we know that g(a)=0.

subsubsection.title: Optional proof of part (b) of l'Hôpital's rule
subsubsection.p: To prove part (b) we must work around the possibility that f'(a) and g'(a) do not exist or that f'(x) and g'(x) are not continuous at x=a. To do this, we make use of the Generalised Mean-Value Theorem (Theorem) that was used to prove Equation. We recommend you review the GMVT before proceeding.

For simplicity we consider the limit
\lim_{x\to a^+} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)}
By assumption, we know that
\lim_{x\to a^+} f(x) = \lim_{x\to a^+} g(x) = 0
For simplicity, we also assume that f(a)=g(a)=0. This allows us to write
\frac{f(x)}{g(x)} &= \frac{f(x)-f(a)}{g(x)-g(a)}
which is the right form for an application of the GMVT.

subsection.title: Standard examples
subsection.p: Here are some simple examples using L'Hôpital's rule.

example.title: Find \ds \lim_{x\to 0} \frac{\sin x}{x}
example.p:
Consider the limit
\lim_{x\to 0} \frac{\sin x}{x}
Notice that
\lim_{x\to 0} \sin x &= 0
\lim_{x\to 0} x &= 0
so this is a \frac00 indeterminate form, and suggests we try l'Hôpital's rule.
To apply the rule we must first check the limits of the derivatives.
f(x)&= \sin x & f'(x) & =\cos x & \text{and} && f'(0)=1
g(x) &= x & g'(x) & = 1 & \text{and} && g'(0)=1
So by l'Hôpital's rule
\lim_{x\to 0} \frac{\sin x}{x} &= \frac{f'(0)}{g'(0)} = \frac{1}{1} = 1.

example.title: Compute \ds \lim_{x\to 0} \frac{\sin(x)}{\sin(2x)}
example.p:
Consider the limit
\lim_{x\to 0} \frac{\sin(x)}{\sin(2x)}
First check
\lim_{x\to 0} \sin 2x &= 0
\lim_{x\to 0} \sin x &= 0
so we again have a \frac00 indeterminate form.
Set f(x)=\sin x and g(x)=\sin 2x, then
f'(x) &= \cos x & f'(0)= 1
g'(x) &= 2\cos 2x & g'(0)= 2
And by l'Hôpital's rule
\lim_{x\to 0} \frac{\sin x}{\sin 2x} &= \frac{f'(0)}{g'(0)} = \frac{1}{2}.

ul.li:
First check
\lim_{x \to 0} (q^x-1) & = 1-1 = 0
\lim_{x \to 0} x & = 0
so we have a \frac00 indeterminate form.

Set f(x)= q^x-1 and g(x)=x, then (maybe after a quick review of Section)
f'(x) &= \diff{}{x}\left(q^x-1\right) = q^x \cdot \log q & f'(0) &= \log q
g'(x) &= 1 & g'(0) &= 1

And by l'Hôpital's rule While it might not be immediately obvious, this example relies on circular reasoning. In order to apply l'Hôpital's rule, we need to compute the derivative of q^x. However in order to compute that limit (see Section) we needed to evaluate this limit. \mbox{ } A more obvious example of this sort of circular reasoning can be seen if we use l'Hôpital's rule to compute the derivative of f(x)=x^n at x=a using the limit
f'(a) = \lim_{x \to a} \frac{x^n -a^n}{x-a} = \lim_{x \to a} \frac{n x^{n-1}-0}{1-0} = n a^{n-1}.
We have used the result \diff{}{x} x^n = nx^{n-1} to prove itself!
\lim_{h \to0} \frac{q^h - 1}{h} &= \log q.

subsection.p: In this example, we shall apply L'Hôpital's rule twice before getting the answer.

example.title: Double L'Hôpital
example.p:
Compute the limit
\lim_{x\to 0} \frac{\sin(x^2)}{1-\cos x}
Again we should check
\lim_{x\to 0} \sin(x^2) &= \sin 0 = 0
\lim_{x\to 0}(1-\cos x) &= 1-\cos 0 = 0
and we have a \frac00 indeterminate form.
Let f(x) = \sin(x^2) and g(x)=1-\cos x then
f'(x) &= 2x\cos(x^2) & f'(0)&=0
g'(x) &= \sin x & g'(0) &=0
So if we try to apply l'Hôpital's rule naively we will get
\lim_{x\to 0} \frac{\sin(x^2)}{1-\cos x} &= \frac{f'(0)}{g'(0)} = \frac{0}{0}.
which is another \frac00 indeterminate form.
It appears that we are stuck until we remember that l'Hôpital's rule (as stated in Theorem) has a part (b) now is a good time to reread it.
It says that
\lim_{x\to 0} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} &= \lim_{x\to 0} \frac{f'(x)}{g'(x)}
provided this second limit exists. In our case this requires us to compute
\lim_{x \to 0} \frac{2x \cos(x^2)}{\sin(x)}
which we can do using l'Hôpital's rule again. Now
h(x) &= 2x\cos(x^2) & h'(x) &= 2\cos(x^2) - 4x^2\sin(x^2) & h'(0) &=2
\ell(x) &= \sin(x) & \ell'(x) &= \cos(x) & \ell'(0) &= 1
By l'Hôpital's rule
\lim_{x \to 0} \frac{2x \cos(x^2)}{\sin(x)} &= \frac{h'(0)}{\ell'(0)} = 2
Thus our original limit is
\lim_{x\to 0} \frac{\sin(x^2)}{1-\cos x} &=\lim_{x \to 0} \frac{2x \cos(x^2)}{\sin(x)} = 2.
We can succinctly summarise the two applications of L'Hôpital's rule in this example by
\lim_{x\to 0}\underbrace{\frac{\sin(x^2)}{1-\cos x}}_{\atp {\mathrm{num}\to 0} {\mathrm{den}\to 0}} &=\lim_{x\to 0}\underbrace{\frac{2x\cos(x^2)}{\sin x}}_{\atp {\mathrm{num}\to 0} {\mathrm{den}\to 0}} =\lim_{x\to 0}\underbrace{\frac{2\cos(x^2)-4x^2\sin(x^2)}{\cos x}}_{\atp {\mathrm{num}\to 2} {\mathrm{den}\to 1}} =2
Here num and den are used as abbreviations of numerator and denominator respectively."

subsection.p: One must be careful to ensure that the hypotheses of l'Hôpital's rule are satisfied before applying it. The following warnings show the sorts of things that can go wrong.

statement.p:
If
\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow a}g(x)&=0 &\text{but}&& \lim\limits_{x\rightarrow a}f(x)&\ne 0
then
\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow a}\frac{f(x)}{g(x)} && \text{need not be the same as} && \lim\limits_{x\rightarrow a}\frac{f'(x)}{g'(x)}.

subsection.p: This next one is more subtle; the limits of the original numerator and denominator functions both go to zero, but the limit of the ratio their derivatives does notexist.

warning.title: Limit of ratio of derivatives DNE

statement.p:
Here is an example. Take
a=0\qquad \qquad f(x)=x^2\sin\frac{1}{x} \qquad g(x)= x
Then (with an application of the squeeze theorem)
\lim_{x\to 0} f(x) &= 0 & \text{and}&& \lim_{x\to 0} g(x) &= 0.
If we attempt to apply l'Hôptial's rule then we have g'(x)=1 and
f'(x)&=2x\sin\frac{1}{x} -\cos\frac{1}{x}
and we then try to compute the limit \lim_{x\to 0} \frac{f'(x)}{g'(x)} &= \lim_{x\to 0} \left( 2x\sin\frac{1}{x} -\cos\frac{1}{x}\right)
However, this limit does not exist. The first term converges to 0 (by the squeeze theorem), but the second term \cos(1/x) just oscillates wildly between \pm 1. All we can conclude from this is

blockquote.p: Since the limit of the ratio of derivatives does not exist, we cannot apply l'Hôpital's rule.

subsection.p:
It is also easy to construct an example in which the limits of numerator and denominator are both zero, but the limit of the ratio and the limit of the ratio of the derivatives do not exist. A slight change of the previous example shows that it is possible that
\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow a}f(x) &=0 & \text{and}&& \lim\limits_{x\rightarrow a}g(x) &= 0
but neither of the limits
\lim\limits_{x\rightarrow a}\frac{f(x)}{g(x)} && \text{or}&& \lim\limits_{x\rightarrow a}\frac{f'(x)}{g'(x)}
exist. Take
a=0\qquad \qquad f(x)=x\sin\frac{1}{x} \qquad g(x)= x
Then (with a quick application of the squeeze theorem)
\lim_{x\to 0} f(x) &= 0 & \text{and}&& \lim_{x\to 0} g(x) &= 0.
However,
\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\frac{f(x)}{g(x)} &=\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\frac{x\sin\frac{1}{x} }{x} =\lim_{x\rightarrow 0} \sin\frac{1}{x}
does not exist. And similarly
\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\frac{f'(x)}{g'(x)} &= \lim_{x\to 0} \frac{\sin\frac{1}{x} - \frac{1}{x}\cos\frac{1}{x} }{x^2}
does not exist.

introduction.p: Theorem is the basic form of L'Hôpital's rule, but there are also many variations. Here are a bunch of them.

subsubsection.title: Limits at \pm \infty
subsubsection.p: L'Hôpital's rule also applies when the limit of x \to a is replaced by \lim\limits_{x\rightarrow a+} or by \lim\limits_{x\rightarrow a-} or by \lim\limits_{x\rightarrow +\infty} or by \lim\limits_{x\rightarrow -\infty}.

We can justify adapting the rule to the limits to \pm \infty via the following reasoning
\lim_{x\to \infty} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} &= \lim_{y \to 0^+} \frac{ f(1/y) }{ g(1/y) } & \text{substitute } x=1/y
&= \lim_{y \to 0^+} \frac{ -\frac{1}{y^2} f'(1/y) } { -\frac{1}{y^2}g'(1/y)},
where we have used l'Hôpital's rule (assuming this limit exists) and the fact that \diff{}{y} f(1/y) = -\frac{1}{y^2} f'(1/y) (and similarly for g). Cleaning this up and substituting y=1/x gives the required result:
\lim_{x\to \infty} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} & =\lim_{y \to 0^+} \frac{f'(1/y)} {g'(1/y)} =\lim_{x\to\infty} \frac{f'(x)}{g'(x)}.

subsubsection.p: L'Hôpital's rule also applies when \lim\limits_{x\rightarrow a}f(x)=0, \lim\limits_{x\rightarrow a}g(x)=0 is replaced \lim\limits_{x\rightarrow a}f(x)=\pm\infty, \lim\limits_{x\rightarrow a}g(x)=\pm\infty.

example.p:
Consider the limit
\lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{\log x}{x}

example.title: Find \ds \lim_{x \to \infty} \frac{5x^2+3x-3}{x^2+1}
A messier double l'Hôpital
example.p:
Compute the limit
\lim_{x\rightarrow 0+} \frac{\log x}{\tan\big(\frac{\pi}{2}-x\big)}

The first application of L'Hôpital's was with
f(x) &= \log x & g(x) &=\tan\Big(\frac{\pi}{2}-x\Big)
f'(x)&=\frac{1}{x}\qquad& g'(x)&=-\sec^2\Big(\frac{\pi}{2}-x\Big)
and the second time with
f(x) &= \cos^2\Big(\frac{\pi}{2}-x\Big) & g(x) &=x
f'(x)&=2\cos\Big(\frac{\pi}{2}-x\Big) \Big[-\sin\Big(\frac{\pi}{2}-x\Big)\Big](-1)\qquad& g'(x)&=1

subsubsection.p: Sometimes things don't quite work out as we would like and l'Hôpital's rule can get stuck in a loop. Remember to think about the problem before you apply any rule.

subsubsection.title: Optional proof of l'Hôpital's rule for \frac\infty\infty
0\cdot\infty indeterminate form
subsubsection.p:
When \ds \lim_{x\to a}f(x) = 0 and \ds \lim_{x\to a} g(x) = \infty. We can use a little algebra to manipulate this into either a \frac{0}{0} or \frac{\infty}{\infty} form:
\lim_{x \to a} \frac{f(x)}{1/g(x)} && \lim_{x \to a} \frac{g(x)}{1/f(x)}

example.p:
Consider the limit
\lim_{x\to 0^+} x \cdot \log x
Here the function f(x)=x goes to zero, while g(x)=\log x goes to -\infty. If we rewrite this as the fraction
x \cdot \log x &= \frac{\log x}{1/x}
then the 0 \cdot \infty form has become an \frac\infty\infty form.

example.title: Compute \ds \lim_{x\to \frac{\pi}{2}^-} \left( \sec x - \tan x\right)

subsubsection.p: In the last example, Example , we converted an \infty-\infty indeterminate form into a \frac{0}{0} indeterminate form by exploiting the fact that the two terms, \sec x and \tan x, in the \infty-\infty indeterminate form shared a common denominator, namely \cos x. In the real world that will, of course, almost never happen. However as the next couple of examples show, you can often massage these expressions into suitable forms.

subsubsection.title: 1^\infty indeterminate form
subsubsection.p:
We can use l'Hôpital's rule on limits of the form
\lim_{x\to a} f(x)^{g(x)} & \text{ with }
\lim_{x\to a} f(x) &= 1 & \text{ and } && \lim_{x \to a} g(x) &= \infty
by considering the logarithm of the limit We are using the fact that the logarithm is a continuous function and Theorem. :
\log\left( \lim_{x\to a} f(x)^{g(x)} \right) &= \lim_{x\to a} \log\left( f(x)^{g(x)} \right) = \lim_{x\to a} \log\left( f(x) \right) \cdot g(x)
which is now an 0 \cdot \infty form. This can be further transformed into a \frac00 or \frac\infty\infty form:
\log\left( \lim_{x\to a} f(x)^{g(x)} \right) &=\lim_{x\to a} \log\left( f(x) \right) \cdot g(x)
&= \lim_{x\to a} \frac{\log\left( f(x) \right)}{1/g(x)}.

example.title: Find \ds \lim_{x\rightarrow 0}(1+x)^{\frac{a}{x}}
example.p:
The following limit appears quite naturally when considering systems which display exponential growth or decay.
\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}(1+x)^{\frac{a}{x}} \qquad\text{with the constant } a\ne 0
Since (1+x) \to 1 and a/x \to \infty this is an 1^\infty indeterminate form.

example.p: This was quite a complicated example. However it does illustrate the importance of cleaning up your algebraic expressions. This will both reduce the amount of work you have to do and will also reduce the number of errors you make.

subsubsection.title: 0^0indeterminate form
subsubsection.p: Like the 1^\infty form, this can be treated by considering its logarithm.

example.title: Compute \ds \lim_{x\rightarrow 0+}x^x
example.p:
For example, in the limit
\lim_{x\rightarrow 0+}x^x
both the base, x, and the exponent, also x, go to zero. But if we consider the logarithm then we have
\log x^x = x\log x
which is a 0\cdot\infty indeterminate form, which we already know how to treat. In fact, we already found, in Example , that
\lim_{x\rightarrow 0+} x\log x=0
Since the exponential is a continuous function
\lim_{x\rightarrow 0+}x^x =\lim_{x\rightarrow 0+}\exp\big(x\log x\big) =\exp\Big(\lim_{x\rightarrow 0+}x\log x\Big) =e^0 =1

subsubsection.title: \infty^0 indeterminate form
subsubsection.p: Again, we can treat this form by considering its logarithm.
